article.title: Bifr%C3%B6st
article.paragraph: other usesBifrost (disambiguation)File:Heimdall an der Himmelsbrcke.jpgthumbThe godHeimdallrstands before the rainbow bridge while blowing a horn (1905) byEmil Doepler.InNorse mythology,Bifrst(IPAc-enˈbɪvrɒstBifrost.oggcite webhttp://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/bifrost?showCookiePolicyDefinition: Bifrostn.d.16 October 2014Collins Dictionaryor sometimesBilrstorBivrost) is a burningrainbowbridge that reaches betweenMidgard(the world) andAsgard, the realm of thesirgods. The bridge is attested asBilrstin thePoetic Edda; compiled in the 13th century from earlier traditional sources, and asBifrstin theProse Edda; written in the 13th century bySnorri Sturluson, and in the poetry ofskalds. Both thePoetic Eddaand theProse Eddaalternately refer to the bridge asAsbr(Old Norse"sir's bridge").Simek (2007:19).

According to theProse Edda, the bridge ends in heaven atHiminbjrg, the residence of the godHeimdallr, who guards it from theJtunnjtnar. The bridge's destruction duringRagnarkby the forces ofMspellsheimrMuspellis foretold. Scholars have proposed that the bridge may have originally represented theMilky Wayand have noted parallels between the bridge and another bridge in Norse mythology,Gjallarbr.
article.heading: Etymology
article.paragraph: ScholarAndy Orchardposits thatBifrstmay mean "shimmering path." He notes that the first element ofBilrstbil(meaning "a moment")"suggests the fleeting nature of the rainbow," which he connects to the first element ofBifrsttheOld Norseverbbifa(meaning "to shimmer" or "to shake")noting that the element provokes notions of the "lustrous sheen" of the bridge.Orchard (1997:19).Austrian GermanistRudolf Simeksays thatBifrsteither means "the swaying road to heaven" (also citingbifa) or, ifBilrstis the original form of the two (which Simek says is likely), "the fleetingly glimpsed rainbow" (possibly connected toHjuki and Bilbil, perhaps meaning "moment, weak point").Simek (2007:36-37).
article.heading: Attestations
article.paragraph: Two poems in thePoetic Eddaand two books in theProse Eddaprovide information about the bridge:

File:Thor wades while the sir ride by Frlich.jpgthumbThor wades through rivers while the rest of the sir ride across Bifrst (1895) byLorenz Frlich.In thePoetic Edda, the bridge is mentioned in the poemsGrmnismlandFfnisml, where it is referred to asBilrst. In one of two stanzas in the poemGrmnismlthat mentions the bridge,List of names of OdinGrmnir(the godOdinin disguise) provides the youngAgnarr GeirrssonAgnarrwith cosmological knowledge, including that Bilrst is the best of bridges.Larrington (1999:44).Later inGrmnisml, Grmnir notes that Asbr "burns all with flames" and that, every day, the godThorwades through the waters ofKrmt and rmtand the twoKerlaugar:Benjamin Thorpetranslation:Krmt and Ormt, and the Kerlaugs twain:these Thor must wadeeach day, when he to council goesatYggdrasil'sash treeash;for as the As-bridge is all on fire,the holy waters boil.Thorpe (1907:22).Henry Adams Bellows (businessman)Henry Adams Bellowstranslation:Kormt and Ormt and the Kerlaugs twainShall Thor each day wade through,(When dooms to give he forth shall goTo the ash-tree Yggdrasil;)For heaven's bridge burns all in flame,And the sacred waters seethe.Bellows (1923:96).

InFfnisml, the dyingwyrm (dragon)wyrmFafnirtells the heroSigurdthat, during the events of Ragnarok, bearing spears, gods will meet atskpnir. From there, the gods will cross Bilrst, which will break apart as they cross over it, causing their horses to dredge through an immense river.Larrington (1999:160).

File:Kampf der untergehenden Gtter by F. W. Heine.jpgthumbBifrst appears in the background as the gods do battle in ''Battle of the Doomed Gods'' (1882) byFriedrich Wilhelm Heine.File:The twilight of the gods by Willy Pogany.pngthumbrightBifrst is shattered in ''The twilight of the gods'' (1920) byWilly Pogany.The bridge is mentioned in theProse EddabooksGylfaginningandSkldskaparml, where it is referred to asBifrst. In chapter 13 ofGylfaginning,GylfiGangleri(KingGylfiin disguise) asks the enthroned figure ofHigh, Just-As-High, and ThirdHighwhat way exists between heaven and earth. Laughing, High replies that the question isn't an intelligent one, and goes on to explain that the gods built a bridge from heaven and earth. He incredulously asks Gangleri if he has not heard the story before. High says that Gangleri must have seen it, and notes that Gangleri may call it arainbow. High says that the bridge consists of three colors, has great strength, "and is built with art and skill to a greater extent than other constructions."Faulkes (1995:15).

High notes that, although the bridge is strong, it will break when "MuspelheimMuspell's lads" attempt to cross it, and their horses will have to make do with swimming over "great rivers." Gangleri says that it doesn't seem that the gods "built the bridge in good faith if it is liable to break, considering that they can do as they please." High responds that the gods do not deserve blame for the breaking of the bridge, for "there is nothing in this world that will be secure when Muspell's sons attack."

In chapter 15 ofGylfaginning,High, Just-As-High, and ThirdJust-As-Highsays that Bifrst is also calledAsbr, and that every day the gods rideHorses of the sirtheir horsesacross it (with the exception of Thor, who instead wades through the boiling waters of the riversKrmt and rmt) to reachUrarbrunnr, a holy well where the gods have their court. As a reference, Just-As-High quotes the second of the two stanzas inGrmnismlthat mention the bridge (see above). Gangleri asks if fire burns over Bifrst. High says that the red in the bridge is burning fire, and, without it, the frost jotnar and mountain jotnar would "go up into heaven" if anyone who wanted could cross Bifrst. High adds that, in heaven, "there are many beautiful places" and that "everywhere there has divine protection around it."Faulkes (1995:1718).

In chapter 17, High tells Gangleri that the location ofHiminbjrg"stands at the edge of heaven where Bifrost reaches heaven."Faulkes (1995:20).While describing the godHeimdallrin chapter 27, High says that Heimdallr lives in Himinbjrg by Bifrst, and guards the bridge from mountain jotnar while sitting at the edge of heaven.Faulkes (1995:25).In chapter 34, High quotes the first of the twoGrmnismlstanzas that mention the bridge.Faulkes (1995:34).In chapter 51, High foretells the events ofRagnark. High says that, during Ragnark, the sky will split open, and from the split will ride forth the "sons ofMuspelheimMuspell". When the "sons of Muspell" ride over Bifrst it will break, "as was said above."Faulkes (1995:53).

In theProse EddabookSkldskaparml, the bridge receives a single mention. In chapter 16, a work by the 10th centuryskaldlfr Uggasonis provided, where Bifrst is referred to as "the powers' way."Faulkes (1995:77).
article.heading: Theories
article.paragraph: Image:Heimdall and little Hnossa by Willy Pogany.pngthumbBifrst in the background, Heimdallr explains to a youngHnosshow all things came to be (1920) byWilly Pogany.In his translation of theProse Edda,Henry Adams Bellows (businessman)Henry Adams Bellowscomments that theGrmnismlstanza mentioning Thor and the bridge stanza may mean that "Thor has to go on foot in the last days of the destruction, when the bridge is burning. Another interpretation, however, is that when Thor leaves the heavens (i.e., when a thunder-storm is over) the rainbow-bridge becomes hot in the sun."

John Lindowpoints to a parallel between Bifrst, which he notes is "a bridge between earth and heaven, or earth and the world of the gods", and the bridgeGjallarbr, "a bridge between earth and the underworld, or earth and the world of the dead."Lindow (2002:81).Several scholars have proposed that Bifrst may represent theMilky Way.Lindow (2002:81) and Simek (2007:36).
